author: By Billy Witz
title: In a Crisis, Even a Gift From the N.C.A.A. Begets Turmoil
description: Baseball players face particularly tough choices after a decision to allow an extra year of eligibility for spring athletes whose seasons were cut short by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Baseball has always spoken to Tyler Kapuscinski. Growing up in Marlboro, N.J., he wrote school papers on Mickey Mantle, his father’s baseball idol, and found his own footing in the batter’s box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Construction in New York Limps Forward Despite Shutdown Order
description: The city is trying to enforce a stop-work order to keep workers safe. But there are exemptions, and many developers want one.
content: Development has ground to a halt across New York City. Or has it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Cristina, Cult Downtown New York Singer, Dies at 64
description: A fixture in New York’s dance-music nightlife of the late ’70s and early ’80s, she gained new attention in 2004 when her albums were reissued.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The Meaning of Life
description: Andrea Carla Michaels and Brian Thomas bring out the solving beasts in us.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s interesting to observe the evolution of a crossword puzzle. Occasionally, an idea might come pouring out of a constructor’s brain in stellar condition, like one of Mozart’s works, but most of the time, puzzle makers spend hours polishing their opuses. That means moving black squares around, hopefully dropping entries or even entire sections that obstruct the build, filtering word lists for crackling entries and rewriting clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Laetitia Vancon
title: Of Beards and Bubonic Plague: German Village Prays for a (2nd) Miracle
description: In 1633 the Bavarian village of Oberammergau, ravaged by a pandemic, made a pledge to God. Now another pandemic has forced villagers to abandon their promise.
content: OBERAMMERGAU, Germany — There is no doubt in the mind of the Rev. Thomas Gröner that what happened in his village was a miracle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Top Democrats Press Treasury to Accelerate Airline Bailout
description: Senator Chuck Schumer and Speaker Nancy Pelosi are urging Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin not to negotiate so aggressively that it deters companies from taking aid to protect workers.
content: WASHINGTON — Top Democratic lawmakers have urged Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to quickly provide American airlines with direct payroll assistance and to avoid insisting on overly restrictive terms that could deter companies from taking the money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The Nurse Was Holding Up. Then Her 3 Close Relatives Were Brought In.
description: After crippling New York City, the coronavirus outbreak is now enveloping New Jersey’s densely packed cities and suburbs.
content: Twelve doctors at her hospital and the chief executive were sickened with the coronavirus. A colleague had died. Patients as young as 19 were being placed on ventilators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Progressives Built an Organizing Juggernaut for 2020. Then the Virus Hit.
description: After a disappointing turn in the presidential race, grass-roots progressive groups focused on congressional races and down-ballot campaigns. In weeks, the coronavirus has destroyed their plans.
content: When it became clear last month that former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. would almost certainly win the Democratic nomination, many of the progressive Democrats who supported other presidential candidates were disappointed but not deterred. They quickly shifted their electoral focus to candidates lower on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zweig
title: They Were the Last Couple in Paradise. Now Their Resort Life Continues.
description: They were surrounded by a fleet of staff, who were stranded themselves, trapped in an eternal honeymoon in the Maldives. Their adventure continues.
content: After publication, this article was updated to reflect new conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: The Nurse Was Holding Up. Then Her 3 Close Relatives Were Brought In.
description: After crippling New York City, the coronavirus outbreak is now enveloping New Jersey’s densely packed cities and suburbs.
content: Twelve doctors at her hospital and the chief executive were sickened with the coronavirus. A colleague had died. Patients as young as 19 were being placed on ventilators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Progressives Built an Organizing Juggernaut for 2020. Then the Virus Hit.
description: After a disappointing turn in the presidential race, grass-roots progressive groups focused on congressional races and down-ballot campaigns. In weeks, the coronavirus has destroyed their plans.
content: When it became clear last month that former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. would almost certainly win the Democratic nomination, many of the progressive Democrats who supported other presidential candidates were disappointed but not deterred. They quickly shifted their electoral focus to candidates lower on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Mystery Shipwreck Dates to Before Revolutionary War, Researcher Says
description: The hull of a ship that surfaces every few years on a Maine beach may have been the Defiance, a sloop built in 1754.
content: In 1769, a cargo ship laden with flour, pork and English goods set sail from Salem, Mass., headed to Portland, Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: This Is What Happens When a Narcissist Runs a Crisis
description: Trump’s catastrophic performance has as much to do with psychology as ideology.
content: Since the early days of the Trump administration, an impassioned group of mental health professionals have warned the public about the president’s cramped and disordered mind, a darkened attic of fluttering bats. Their assessments have been controversial. The American Psychiatric Association’s code of ethics expressly forbids its members from diagnosing a public figure from afar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Barkhorn
title: Rules for Using the Sidewalk During the Coronavirus
description: Going outside is still a joy. But we all need to do more to walk and run while social distancing.
content: As state after state has announced coronavirus stay-at-home orders, one bright spot remains: It’s still OK to go for a walk. (If you’re not sick, and if you wear a mask and keep six feet away from everyone outside your household.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: What Does a Sports Desk Do When Sports Are on Hold?
description: A cascade of postponements and cancellations upended the coverage that Times editors and reporters had planned. So they called a different play.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Trump Again Promotes Use of Unproven Anti-Malaria Drug; Deaths in Country May Be Undercounted
description: For the second straight day, the president pushed the use of hydroxychloroquine, which has not been proven to treat the coronavirus. Washington State is returning 400 ventilators to be redeployed to states in more dire need.
content: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘10 Years of Change in One Week’: Telemedicine on Fast Track in Britain
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 5, 2020.
content: “It definitely is medicine in the dark. There’s a concern that if we’re bringing in patients less, we may not be seeing more subtle signs of things like cancer.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: The Battle Over the Sea-Monkey Fortune
description: A story as crazy as it sounds.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sam Hunt and Kenny Rogers, Country Music Rule-Benders
description: Both artists pulled Nashville in fresh directions, and gave the genre growing pains.
content: As certainly as country music tells a story about itself — it is rural, it is authentic — there are dissenters tugging it in new directions. Often those dissenters end up becoming revered in hindsight, even if their loyalties were questioned in the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Larissa Garbade, Jacob Yosafat
description: The couple met in 2017 through the dating app JSwipe.
content: Larissa Louise Garbade and Jacob David Yosafat were married April 4 in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Clifford M. Kulwin officiated at the home of the bride’s parents. The couple had originally planned to marry that same day at the Weylin, an events space in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: The Battle Over the Sea-Monkey Fortune
description: A story as crazy as it sounds.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sam Hunt and Kenny Rogers, Country Music Rule-Benders
description: Both artists pulled Nashville in fresh directions, and gave the genre growing pains.
content: As certainly as country music tells a story about itself — it is rural, it is authentic — there are dissenters tugging it in new directions. Often those dissenters end up becoming revered in hindsight, even if their loyalties were questioned in the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: In ‘Afropessimism,’ a Black Intellectual Mixes Memoir and Theory
description: Frank B. Wilderson III talks about his experimental approach to writing about blackness and violence, as well as the solace he found in Sarah Vaughan.
content: In his new book, “Afropessimism,” Frank B. Wilderson III writes that earlier in life he saw himself, as an African-American, “as a degraded Human,” his plight “analogous to the plight of the Palestinians, the Native American and the working class.” But at some point he came to question this comparison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 6, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: With Campaigns in Remote Mode, Pandemic Upends Battle for Congress
description: As retail campaigning has become all but impossible amid the public health crisis, candidates tread carefully in an uncertain political environment.
content: WASHINGTON — As John Hickenlooper, the former Colorado governor and current Democratic candidate for Senate, began another campaign event via Facebook Live last week, he stated the obvious to his virtual audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: How New Jersey’s First Coronavirus Patient Survived
description: James Cai’s case was completely new to his doctors. When he grew severely ill, he tapped a network of Chinese and Chinese-American medical colleagues who helped save his life.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers, like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Periods Don’t Stop for Pandemics, So She Brings Pads to Women in Need
description: Coronavirus has led to a rush on menstrual products. As with other supplies, those who can afford to hoard have done so, leaving women with lower incomes without basic essentials.
content: — Dana Marlowe, founder and executive director of the nonprofit I Support the Girls
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak and Patrick Kingsley
title: Hungary’s Leader Grabbed Powers to Fight the Virus. Some Fear Other Motives.
description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban can now rule by decree. Doctors worry he won’t use that power to improve the country’s coronavirus response.
content: BUDAPEST — In the days since the Hungarian Parliament gave Prime Minister Viktor Orban the right to rule indefinitely by decree, nominally in the name of combating the coronavirus pandemic, his government has been energized by much other than the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Vanessa Swales
title: Amid Warnings of a Coronavirus ‘Pearl Harbor,’ Governors Walk a Fine Line
description: As officials warned people to brace for a surge in cases and deaths, governors pleaded for a consistent strategy and more help from Washington.
content: As the surgeon general told the nation to brace for “our Pearl Harbor moment” of cascading coronavirus deaths this week, several governors said on Sunday that their states were in urgent need of federal help and complained that they had been left to compete for critical equipment in the absence of a consistent strategy and coordination from the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Sunshine and Shyam Gollakota
title: Alexa, Do I Have Coronavirus?
description: There’s a way to bring in big tech without compromising our privacy.
content: SEATTLE — One in four U.S. households have a smart speaker and 81 percent of adults own a smartphone. These devices might seem to be unlikely medical instruments, yet their computing capability, storage and sensor quality is often superior to the clinical-grade equipment used to monitor patients in an intensive care unit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Phillips-Fein
title: Scapegoating New York Means Ignoring Its Desperate Need
description: Blaming the city for coronavirus is a way of letting the federal government off the hook.
content: The anxious notes have been arriving in my inbox from people all over the country: “Watching reports and wanted to check in.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Stephens-Davidowitz
title: Google Searches Can Help Us Find Emerging Covid-19 Outbreaks
description: They can also reveal symptoms that at first went undetected. I may have found a new one.
content: Every day, millions of people around the world type their health symptoms into Google. We can use these searches to help detect unknown Covid-19 outbreaks, particularly in parts of the world with poor testing infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Novak and Patrick Kingsley
title: Hungary’s Leader Grabbed Powers to Fight the Virus. Some Fear Other Motives.
description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban can now rule by decree. Doctors worry he won’t use that power to improve the country’s coronavirus response.
content: BUDAPEST — In the days since the Hungarian Parliament gave Prime Minister Viktor Orban the right to rule indefinitely by decree, nominally in the name of combating the coronavirus pandemic, his government has been energized by much other than the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
title: He Led a Top Navy Ship. Now He Sits in Quarantine, Fired and Infected.
description: Colleagues say the downfall of Capt. Brett E. Crozier was charging headlong into the Trump administration’s narrative that it had everything in the coronavirus pandemic under control.
content: WASHINGTON — For days, he fended off fears that the contagion would spread unchecked through his crew. Then last week, the captain of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, who had appealed to his superiors for help, was fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: Politics Through the Looking Glass: Virus Scrambles the Left-Right Lines
description: A huge federal disaster response, new urgency around health care and a debate over social distancing have muddled the nation’s ideological debate.
content: The 2020 edition of the Conservative Political Action Conference in Oxon Hill, Md., in February offered a theme-park version of what was to be President Trump’s re-election message: Under the banner of “America vs. Socialism,” the convention featured anti-Marx branded popcorn, an RV emblazed with the words “Socialism Takes Capitalism Creates” and a children’s book promoting personal freedom and private-property rights.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Grim Planning: Wills, Estates, Health Care Proxies …
description: A lawyer and an end-of-life educator stress the importance of executing these documents, now more than ever. Also: Prostate cancer; voting by mail.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Bible Museum, Admitting Mistakes, Tries to Convert Its Critics
description: In acknowledging that many of its artifacts had tainted histories and that others were fake, the institution hopes candor will build trust.
content: For all its stated good intentions, when the Museum of the Bible in Washington was first envisioned a decade ago, skeptics worried it would favor religious proselytizing over neutral scholarship and buttoned-down collecting practices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Daniel Bering, Robert Strain
description: The couple met in 2016 in San Francisco through the dating app Tinder.
content: Daniel Richardson Bering and Robert Marshall Strain were married April 4 on a walking trail at the Thornton State Beach in Daly City, Calif. Heather Smith, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Hotel Peter and Paul in New Orleans before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed. They plan to have a reception there Nov. 22.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jamie Fishkin, Seth Faber
description: They knew each other since they were in the same toddler playgroup in Great Neck, N.Y.
content: Jamie Hannah Fishkin and Seth Eric Faber were married April 4 at the house of the groom’s parents in Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y., before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed. They plan to have another ceremony there July 11.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jamie Fishkin, Seth Faber
description: They knew each other since they were in the same toddler playgroup in Great Neck, N.Y.
content: Jamie Hannah Fishkin and Seth Eric Faber were married April 4 at the house of the groom’s parents in Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated. The couple had originally planned to wed at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y., before the Centers for Disease Control recommended that events with 50 or more be postponed. They plan to have another ceremony there July 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Grim Numbers Get Even Worse
description: The coronavirus has cost nearly 10 million people their jobs. What comes next?
content: There’s no way to sugarcoat what was a truly dismal week, and prospects aren’t much better for the next one. Here’s what you need to know to gear up for the days ahead. Be safe out (or, I should say, in) there. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Louis C.K. Drops a Comeback Special
description: The streaming set is a shorter version of the show he toured last year, and was released the same day as Laugh Aid, a benefit for struggling comics.
content: On Saturday, with audiences largely quarantined in their homes because of the coronavirus, and comics putting on a six-hour benefit online, Laugh Aid, to help struggling performers, Louis C.K. completed the last stage of his comeback with the surprise release of a new special, “Sincerely.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison McCann, Nadja Popovich and Jin Wu
title: Italy’s Virus Shutdown Came Too Late. What Happens Now?
description: Italy underestimated the spread of the virus at first. These maps show why the country’s nationwide lockdown came too late to contain it.
content: Italy underestimated the spread of the virus at first. These maps show why the country’s nationwide lockdown came too late to contain it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook Hampers Do-It-Yourself Mask Efforts
description: The social network said it had made an “error” in threatening to ban the organizers of hand-sewn masks from posting or commenting on its site.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — As health workers on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic plead for personal protective equipment, volunteer efforts to create hand-sewn masks and deliver them to medical professionals have quickly sprung up across the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Tom Dempsey, Record-Setting Kicker, Dies at 73
description: He was born without toes on his right foot, but spent 11 seasons in the N.F.L. and kicked 159 field goals. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: How Economists, Too, Are Taking On the Coronavirus Crisis
description: The pandemic has prompted many in the field to focus on ways to address it and anticipate its aftermath.
content: Ernesto Stein, an economist at the Inter-American Development Bank, normally spends his time thinking about industrial policy in Latin America. But recently, a map in The New York Times caught his eye. It illustrated how hospital systems in some regions of the United States would be quickly overwhelmed by the spread of the coronavirus while others still had resources to spare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Chris Hamby
title: Another Thing to Fear Out There: Coronavirus Scammers
description: The authorities say there has been a surge in fraud and cons seeking to capitalize on fears of the virus.
content: The white banner with images of red crosses had been hastily erected in front of two pop-up tents at a convenience store parking lot in central Louisville, Ky. “Covid-19 testing here,” it read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Kate Conger
title: Gaps in Amazon’s Response as Virus Spreads to More Than 50 Warehouses
description: Shifting sick-leave policy and communication issues are causing employees to assert themselves after they stayed on the job.
content: SEATTLE — Jonathan Bailey, a 30-year-old Amazon warehouse employee in Queens, has a system for protecting himself from the coronavirus at work. He wears a medical mask with a bandanna tied over it. When he returns to the apartment he shares with his wife, he dumps his mask, work gloves, neon green Amazon safety vest and other clothes into a plastic trash bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Chinese Human Rights Lawyer Released From Prison
description: Wang Quanzhang, who took up sensitive cases, had been sentenced in China to four and a half years for “subversion of state power.”
content: HONG KONG — A Chinese human rights lawyer who took up sensitive cases of journalists, democracy advocates and followers of banned spiritual movements was released from prison on Sunday after being held for nearly five years, his wife said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Does Coronavirus Bring a New Perspective on Climate Change?
description: Readers discuss the effect of the virus on the environment going forward.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison McCann, Nadja Popovich and Jin Wu
title: Italy’s Virus Shutdown Came Too Late. What Happens Now?
description: Italy underestimated the spread of the virus at first. These maps show why the country’s nationwide lockdown came too late to contain it.
content: Italy underestimated the spread of the virus at first. These maps show why the country’s nationwide lockdown came too late to contain it.

title: Another Thing to Fear Out There: Coronavirus Scammers
description: The authorities say there has been a surge in fraud and cons seeking to capitalize on fears of the virus.
content: The white banner with images of red crosses had been hastily erected in front of two pop-up tents at a convenience store parking lot in central Louisville, Ky. “Covid-19 testing here,” it read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cui Tiankai
title: China and the U.S. Must Cooperate Against Coronavirus
description: This is a time for solidarity, collaboration and mutual support.
content: WASHINGTON — New York is my favorite American city. I used to live and work there and have been a frequent visitor since I became China’s ambassador to the United States. As Covid-19 continues to sweep across the world, it is sad to see the bustling, sleepless metropolis put on hold. What we are experiencing is a challenge of such magnitude that nationality and ethnicity should be irrelevant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As I Was Walking, I Saw a Woman Step Out of a Building Holding a Jar’
description: A sidewalk twist in the Village, a helpful barber in the Bronx and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus, Masks, Larry David: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Find comfort in scalloped potatoes, chicken cutlets or a classic lasagna.
content: Good morning. Maybe it’s all the John Burdett I’m reading, or the long hours isolated from others, the invisible threat at the gas pump or supermarket or some combination thereof, but while I’m cooking these days I’ve been thinking a lot about the Buddhist teacher Chogyam Trungpa, and about a line of his that’s about living in a world of suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: What’s the Best Material for a Mask?
description: Scientists are testing everyday items to find the best protection from coronavirus. Pillow cases, flannel pajamas and origami vacuum bags are all candidates.
content: Federal health officials have now recommended that we cover our faces with fabric during the coronavirus pandemic. But what material offers the most protection?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francisco Cantú
title: In Her First Adult Novel in 14 Years, Julia Alvarez Travels Home
description: In “Afterlife,” even privilege can’t shield a Dominican-American widow from the immigrant’s plight.
content: AFTERLIFE By Julia Alvarez
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Coronavirus, Assam Tribunals, Global Recession: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Mary Roman, City Clerk Who Set Senior Shot Put Records, Dies at 84
description: Mrs. Roman excelled at many field events, as well as local government. She succumbed to the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Find comfort in scalloped potatoes, chicken cutlets or a classic lasagna.
content: Good morning. Maybe it’s all the John Burdett I’m reading, or the long hours isolated from others, the invisible threat at the gas pump or supermarket or some combination thereof, but while I’m cooking these days I’ve been thinking a lot about the Buddhist teacher Chogyam Trungpa, and about a line of his that’s about living in a world of suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Navy Captain Removed From Carrier Tests Positive for Covid-19
description: Captain Crozier was fired after a leak of a letter he had emailed to Navy leaders detailing the service's failures in dealing with a coronavirus outbreak on the U.S.S. Theodore Roosevelt.
content: Capt. Brett E. Crozier, the Navy captain who was removed from command of the coronavirus-stricken aircraft carrier U.S.S. Theodore Roosevelt, has tested positive for Covid-19, according to two Naval Academy classmates of Crozier’s who are close to him and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Learning to Listen to, and Beyond, the Siren’s Call
description: A music critic’s soundscape has been reshaped by the wail of ambulances. But she’s learning to hear in unexpected ways.
content: For the past five years I have lived a mile from the Brooklyn Hospital Center — though I’m a bit ashamed to say that I did not realize it until a few weeks ago. I am fortunate to have until now moved through life with a breezy ignorance of the nearest hospital’s location. But that unawareness has been punctured hundreds, maybe thousands, of times over the past few weeks by a sound that has become my and my neighbors’ near constant companion: the sirens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: Finland, ‘Prepper Nation of the Nordics,’ Isn’t Worried About Masks
description: Unlike their neighbors, the Finns never stopped stockpiling after the Cold War. Now Finland sits on an enviable supply of medical and survival gear in the Covid-19 era.
content: STOCKHOLM — As some nations scramble to find protective gear to fight the coronavirus pandemic, Finland is sitting on an enviable stockpile of personal protective equipment like surgical masks, putting it ahead of less-prepared Nordic neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
title: Coronavirus Strands China’s Students, in a Dilemma for Beijing
description: The government fears returnees who have been studying abroad could worsen the outbreak. But leaving them hanging risks making the authorities look like they can’t protect people.
content: One student fantasized about buying a $30,000 seat on a private jet. One mother, frustrated with her inability to bring her daughter home, sent masks instead. One group of desperate parents made an unusually public appeal to the Chinese government for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: The Rising Heroes of the Coronavirus Era? Nations’ Top Scientists
description: Scientists in Europe are becoming household names, fulfilling societies’ emotional and practical need for the truth.
content: BRUSSELS — If it weren’t the age of social distancing, people would stop them on the street to take selfies. Instead, they get adoring messages on social media. Others appear on television daily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma, Kai Schultz and Rebecca Conway
title: As Himalayas Warm, Nepal’s Climate Migrants Struggle to Survive
description: Pushed out of their village by a drought and lack of food, a group of Nepalis are fighting to amplify the voices of those forced to relocate by the planet’s warming.
content: DHYE, Nepal — High in the Himalayas, on a rugged plateau dotted with empty mud huts, an exodus has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: How to Live in the Face of Fear: Lessons From a Cancer Survivor
description: Kate Bowler is a religion scholar and best-selling author who is sharing daily reflections on Instagram.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic spreads, the normal touchstones of everyday life have vanished without so much as a warning. In their place are terrifying thoughts about the future, about loss and about mortality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Arnold
title: The Best Thing About NASCAR’s Virtual Races Might Be the Real Competition
description: The sport’s drivers compete from home, the announcers call it like a real race, Fox Sports broadcasts it on TV and nobody gets hurt.
content: When Denny Hamlin’s No. 11 Toyota sped across the finish line at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Florida last month, the victory was unlike any he had experienced. Trailing Dale Earnhardt Jr. on the race’s final lap, Hamlin, the 2006 NASCAR Cup Series rookie of the year, made a final push coming out of Turn 4 and surged past Earnhardt to win a race he had led for only 14 of the 150 laps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: Finland, ‘Prepper Nation of the Nordics,’ Isn’t Worried About Masks
description: Unlike their neighbors, the Finns never stopped stockpiling after the Cold War. Now Finland sits on an enviable supply of medical and survival gear in the Covid-19 era.
content: STOCKHOLM — As some nations scramble to find protective gear to fight the coronavirus pandemic, Finland is sitting on an enviable stockpile of personal protective equipment like surgical masks, putting it ahead of less-prepared Nordic neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Daily Death Toll in N.Y. Sees a One-Day Drop, Cuomo Says
description: On Sunday, New York State reported 594 new deaths, but 630 the day before. The governor cautioned that it could be a “blip.”
content: New York State has now topped 4,000 deaths from the coronavirus, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Sunday. But the governor pointed to early indications that the crisis could be plateauing, though he cautioned against jumping to any conclusions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: I Miss Singing at Church
description: The coronavirus crisis reminds us that we are bodies, not simply souls trapped in a mortal prison.
content: I miss things I did not know I would.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben McVane
title: I’m a Doctor at the ‘Epicenter of the Epicenter’
description: Let’s not forget the social failures that allowed Covid-19 to overwhelm neighborhoods like Elmhurst in Queens.
content: “Do you think I’ll get through this?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Social Distancing Is a Privilege
description: The idea that this virus is an equal-opportunity killer must itself be killed.
content: People like to say that the coronavirus is no respecter of race, class or country, that the disease Covid-19 is mindless and will infect anybody it can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Rafael Gómez Nieto, Last Member of Unit That Helped Liberate Paris, Dies at 99
description: Mr. Gómez, a veteran of the Spanish Civil War who served in a French unit that entered Paris in 1944, was infected by the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times
